content: Oh hey you guys I'm dieppe Scottie welcome
to the craft today I'm going to show you a little craft that did making a pit for
my 2.5 D tiles but I have an interesting technique that I discovered and I wanted
to share that with you - that's me part of the craft you know when we're when
we're crafting you know part of it is to just try stuff you know try things see
if they work sometimes you can happy accidents sometimes you don't but if it
doesn't work hey you learn something and you don't do it next time or you modify
it so you start to learn the properties of the tools and the materials you work
with and then you you experiment so this was a little experimentation I did and I
think it came out quite nice so let's go to the table I'll show you what I came
up with all right so before I talk about the
business of hand I want to show you guys something I found these
actually a Walmart in the cake section and these are set up for molds and you
can see there's different textures there's like a brick like a small stone
there's like a wood texture and like a small our larger stem okay so I thought
hmm I'm gonna be able to make some textures out of these plastic sheets so
what I did was I got some my famous TP sprayed took one of these sheets sprayed
it with water with a spray gun then I put some glue on it some white glue then
I started laying toilet paper sheets on it and when I laid the first layer I
sprayed it again put some more glue laid a second layer and then what I did was I
let it dry okay and you have to let it dry very well or it'll stick to this and
won't come off correctly so let it let it dry and since this is plastic this
side isn't permeable so it seems to take a while to dry but I came up with an
interesting result and here's what I came up with I hope you can see that
okay it's got texture on it okay and it's got like the brick texture all
right so that's just TP and glue that's all that is and it's like that's like a
flexible it's almost like a card stock with a texture on it as you can see it
did the texture didn't pick up perfectly but you know for us that are doing
dungeons and stuff like that hey that's pretty cool you know so what I did was
for this project I was going to use us to ring the pit these stone pieces to
ring there are these stone impressions to ring the pit so I'm gonna cut a layer
of this off and then I'm gonna ring the pit with it
so here we go I've showed the basic pit that I assembled so I took a piece of
cardstock cut that there so it would fit the hallway that I'm using and then I
use some cocktail coffee stirrers and cut those to form a square on the top on
the piece of cardstock then I cut the impressions the the textured impressions
I made and put those on the edge of the coffee stirrers so it gives a makes a
pit with a little bit of a raised area and with that that detail on the edge
now here we go I've cut the excess off and I have painted it up with the pewter
gray I haven't done the highlight yet and I haven't done the perspective into
the pit yet so let's go to the table and I'll show you the finished look and talk
about a little bit so say our adventurers are exploring a deep dank
dungeon and they come to a corner and they go around and then you could put
what they see and so they see this pit there okay and I really like it because
the stone the stone blocks kind of differentiated between the 2.5 D it's
pretty close to the height it's not quite the same height as a 2.5 D but
it's pretty close so it but it does it is nice cuz it differentiates it from
the rest and I did when I painted this I did a faint perspective you know when
you're looking down if you're not familiar with respective you can look it
up online if there's tons about it so basically what I tried to do was if
you're looking down this pit okay you'll see the blocks kind of going in like
this alright so what I did was it's hard to see on this because I darkened them
up but I did the I painted blocks on the inside going in perspective and so the
pit looks like it's going down so I thought that was pretty neat
I also when I painted it I used a black wash over it so just - you can just
barely see it I'm not sure how well the camera is picking it up but it yeah it's
there so this kind of gives a a nice impression that the pit is going down
without actually going anywhere so there we go that's a easy way to make a pit
perspective pit and I'll see you next time on the craft
hey you yeah you back here huh I know we're short but would he expect there's
a short tip watch longer episodes if you want geez
quit bugging me hey and make sure you join the forum too much for that
oh yeah and have a magical craft tastic day
